quotes.topic_title: Journalists serve audiences, not founders
quotes.text: They don't care about you. They don't care about you. They care about their reader or their listener or their viewer.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Reframes PR as audience service, not founder-centric promotion, which changes how you craft pitches.

quotes.topic_title: Journalists serve audiences, not founders
quotes.text: That's who they're serving, and if you can be of use to them in sharing the kinds of information that they are looking to serve their audience, then you can get what you want.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Provides a practical mental model: align your story with what the journalist needs to deliver value to their audience.

quotes.topic_title: Journalists serve audiences, not founders
quotes.text: But you can't treat them like a service provider because they're not.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Warns against a common pitching mistake that leads to immediate disinterest from journalists.

quotes.topic_title: Journalists serve audiences, not founders
quotes.text: And so you have to approach them with an understanding of what they're trying to do for their audience and how you can fit into that because if you don't, they are not interested in you.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Gives an actionable criterion for outreach: demonstrate fit with the publication’s audience mission or expect rejection.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we get incredibly tactical about how to get press for your product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Sets the expectation that the episode will focus on practical, step-by-step tactics rather than high-level theory.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Jason shares how to pitch a journalist, how to find the right journalist to pitch, what publications to consider, why freelance writers are more likely to write about your story, why the mission of the publication is so important in how you pitch them, plus what channels to use to reach out to journalists, how to think about your goals and what success looks like from getting press, so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A dense checklist of actionable levers for getting press, including the counterintuitive angle that freelancers may be more receptive.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: One of the most effective ways to create a big leap in your career, and something that worked really well for me a few years ago, is to create a personal board of directors, a trusted peer group where you can discuss challenges you're having, get career advice, and just kind of gut check how you're thinking about your work, your career, and your life.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Offers a concrete career-growth methodology (a personal board of directors) with clear intended benefits and use cases.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: One of the most effective ways to create a big leap in your career, and something that worked really well for me a few years ago, is to create a personal board of directors, a trusted peer group where you can discuss challenges you're having, get career advice, and just kind of gut check how you're thinking about your work, your career, and your life.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Offers a concrete career-growth tactic (a “personal board of directors”) and what to use it for in practice.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Sidebar, senior leaders are matched with highly vetted, private, supportive peer groups to lean on for unbiased opinions, diverse perspectives, and raw feedback.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a structured method for getting higher-quality feedback (vetted peers + unbiased, diverse perspectives).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Everyone has their own zone of genius, so together, we're better prepared to navigate professional pitfalls, leading to more responsibility, faster promotions, and bigger impact.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable mental model (“zone of genius”) tied to a practical outcome of peer groups: avoiding pitfalls and accelerating growth.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Why spend a decade finding your people when you can meet them at Sidebar today?
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing that challenges the assumption that building a trusted network must take years.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Jump the growing wait list of thousands of leaders from top tech companies by visiting sidebar.com/lenny to learn more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete data point (“thousands of leaders”) indicating demand and social proof for the peer-group approach.

quotes.topic_title: Pitch volume and inbox noise reality
quotes.text: I would say that by the time we are done recording this podcast, I'll have, I don't know. I mean, it could be anywhere from 30 to 50 pitches in my inbox.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: A concrete data point that quantifies inbox competition, underscoring why pitches must be sharply differentiated to get attention.

quotes.topic_title: Pitch volume and inbox noise reality
quotes.text: To reach out to somebody in media is to be shouting over a lot of noise.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that frames pitching as an attention-allocation problem, pushing practitioners to optimize for relevance and clarity.

quotes.topic_title: Pitch volume and inbox noise reality
quotes.text: The percentage of direct messages from founders that I'm getting is low. I would say probably 20, 25%. And then the 75% is PR in some capacity, either targeted PR where somebody's intentionally reaching out to me or mass blast press releases.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: A practical breakdown of who’s pitching, helping founders decide whether direct outreach could be a differentiator versus PR-heavy channels.

quotes.topic_title: Pitch volume and inbox noise reality
quotes.text: But one of the great insights that you can get into the challenges of that industry is how completely automated a lot of it is where a lot of people in PR are not thinking specifically about how to tell the right story to the right potential media outlet. Instead, what they're doing is they're just playing a numbers game, and they're just blasting it out to everybody.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: A counterintuitive critique of PR “scale,” pointing to specificity (right story/right outlet) as the real leverage to stand out.

quotes.topic_title: Pitch volume and inbox noise reality
quotes.text: And I think that's a real disservice to entrepreneurs who are paying for people to do that, and I really hate that.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: A blunt warning that paying for automated blasting can waste money and harm outcomes, reinforcing the value of intentional, tailored pitching.

quotes.topic_title: What press can (and can’t) do
quotes.text: I have had entrepreneurs tell me that a single story in Entrepreneur Magazine, like the print magazine or just online, will drive more, whatever more app downloads, more sales that month than any of their paid marketing efforts.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Highlights the upside case where one strong press hit can outperform paid marketing in the short term.

quotes.topic_title: What press can (and can’t) do
quotes.text: It's all over the gamut, and it's a really important thing for people to remember is that this is not something that I think that you should bank on as a strategy for growth.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: A clear warning to treat press as unreliable and not a primary growth lever.

quotes.topic_title: What press can (and can’t) do
quotes.text: It's a great add-on.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: A simple mental model: press works best as a supplement to an existing growth strategy, not the core of it.

quotes.topic_title: What press can (and can’t) do
quotes.text: But if you think that press by itself is going to solve your problems, you're wrong because it might, but it's way too unpredictable.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Counterintuitive framing that even when press can work, its unpredictability makes it a risky bet as a standalone solution.

quotes.topic_title: When to pursue press: define your purpose
quotes.text: Think about press the same way that you think about raising money, which is to say you do it when you know what the money is for, and you should do it when you know what the press is for.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: A clear mental model for treating press as a strategic resource with a defined purpose, not a default activity.

quotes.topic_title: When to pursue press: define your purpose
quotes.text: A lot of people reach out to me at such an early stage that if we wrote about them, it wouldn't get them anything.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Highlights the common mistake of pursuing press too early, when it can’t translate into meaningful outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: When to pursue press: define your purpose
quotes.text: You should step back and think really as a starting point, "What do I need press for?"
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic question to decide whether press is worth the time investment right now.

quotes.topic_title: When to pursue press: define your purpose
quotes.text: But, "I deserve this" that's not a good tactical decision for your business that doesn't do anything for you.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Separates emotional motivation from business strategy, warning against chasing press for validation.

quotes.topic_title: When to pursue press: define your purpose
quotes.text: You shouldn't go out and try to get press if you don't know what the press is for.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: A simple rule-of-thumb for timing press efforts based on clear, measurable business objectives.

quotes.topic_title: Choose the right publication for your market
quotes.text: Oftentimes, it's not even about the moment, but it's about the publication.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Reframes PR strategy away from timing and toward choosing outlets whose audience matches your conversion goals.

quotes.topic_title: Choose the right publication for your market
quotes.text: Press is to drive hotdog sales. That's what he wants to do. Entrepreneur is not going to do that for him. Full stop. Why? Because Entrepreneur reaches a national to international audience.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that bigger, national press can be useless if it doesn't reach people who can actually buy.

quotes.topic_title: Choose the right publication for your market
quotes.text: So that means that 99.5% of the people who would read a story about this guy have no ability to go get his hotdogs, which means that that was wasted effort.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Quantifies the mismatch between audience reach and buyer access, highlighting why targeting matters more than exposure.

quotes.topic_title: Choose the right publication for your market
quotes.text: What he needs to do is think, "Okay, my goal, get more people to buy hot dogs. Where am I? I'm in Washington, DC. How can I reach people who are interested in food in my market?"
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Provides a practical goal-location-audience question sequence to select the right press targets.

quotes.topic_title: Choose the right publication for your market
quotes.text: So stop chasing Entrepreneur and start chasing the local eater or the food section of the Washingtonian or something like that. That small shift can give you a lot more payoff for your effort.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to prioritize local, high-intent outlets over prestige publications for better ROI.

quotes.topic_title: Three-step framework: prep, target, pitch
quotes.text: So I mean, look, it is pretty simple, right. Step one is prep.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Introduces a simple, repeatable three-step framework for getting press that starts with preparation.

quotes.topic_title: Three-step framework: prep, target, pitch
quotes.text: Step two is figuring out who to pitch. Not all press is created equal. There are not reasons to just go chasing everybody arbitrarily.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Emphasizes targeted outreach over broad, unfocused pitching to maximize relevance and results.

quotes.topic_title: Three-step framework: prep, target, pitch
quotes.text: But what you need to understand is that you're entering a world that probably doesn't operate the way in which you think it does, and I see that all the time as the recipient of pitches.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Highlights a key mindset shift: media operates differently than founders assume, so default pitching instincts often fail.

quotes.topic_title: Three-step framework: prep, target, pitch
quotes.text: And to me, it always feels like they're ordering a hamburger from me. Like, "How do I get a hamburger from Entrepreneur Hamburgers, right?" They're treating me like a service provider. That my job is to provide press.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: A memorable metaphor that explains the common mistake of treating journalists as a press-delivery service.

quotes.topic_title: Three-step framework: prep, target, pitch
quotes.text: The editor, the writer, I'll just say it as plainly as possible, they don't care about you. They don't care about you. They care about their reader, or their listener, or their viewer.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Clarifies the core incentive of media: serving the audience, which should shape how you frame your story and pitch.

quotes.topic_title: Publication mission shapes what gets covered
quotes.text: But it's going to be more specific based on the mission of each publication.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: A practical reminder that getting covered starts with understanding a publication’s specific mission, not just its general category.

quotes.topic_title: Publication mission shapes what gets covered
quotes.text: Entrepreneur, totally different mission. The way that I think of Entrepreneur is that it's not even a magazine about business. It's a magazine about thinking.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: A memorable framing that helps practitioners tailor pitches to the publication’s underlying promise to readers (e.g., “how to think,” not “what to buy”).

quotes.topic_title: Publication mission shapes what gets covered
quotes.text: This is not interesting to us, right. Maybe this is interesting for a cooking magazine, right. Maybe Bon Appétit is interested in this. Entrepreneur's not interested in this because that doesn't help other entrepreneurs to have thought through that problem.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Clarifies the counterintuitive idea that a good product isn’t automatically a good story for every outlet—relevance is defined by reader benefit.

quotes.topic_title: Publication mission shapes what gets covered
quotes.text: And then, one day, she's sitting at the airport waiting to board a flight, and she looks around and she realizes that airports are full of people who have absolutely nothing better to do than answer questions about butter dishes, right.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: A concrete example of scrappy, replicable market research that turns a mundane setting into a high-leverage customer insight channel.

quotes.topic_title: Publication mission shapes what gets covered
quotes.text: You have to step back and read what these publications are publishing and ask yourself, "What are they doing? What is the purpose here?"
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Actionable pitching methodology: reverse-engineer editorial intent by analyzing published patterns before reaching out.

quotes.topic_title: How to infer a publication’s mission
quotes.text: Nobody publishes an about page in that way because the internal logic of the editorial team.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Counters the common assumption that you can find a publication’s true editorial mission on an “about” page, pushing you to infer it from output instead.

quotes.topic_title: How to infer a publication’s mission
quotes.text: But you can certainly make some starting assumptions based on who the publication is trying to reach. Everybody is trying to reach somebody.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Gives a practical starting point for reverse-engineering editorial priorities: identify the target audience first.

quotes.topic_title: How to infer a publication’s mission
quotes.text: You sort of have to divide it up into sections, right. The mission of the National News Desk is different from the mission of the Business Desk, and even within there, the mission of the Sunday business section is different from the mission of the Monday to Saturday business section.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Provides a concrete methodology for broad outlets: treat each desk/section (and even sub-sections) as having its own mission.

quotes.topic_title: How to infer a publication’s mission
quotes.text: But I really do think that if you spent time with the content and your starting point is, "I understand that this publication is trying to reach X. They're trying to reach these people," then you can start to see the patterns of what it is that they're doing.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Actionable advice to study content systematically, using audience as the lens to detect repeatable editorial patterns.

quotes.topic_title: How to infer a publication’s mission
quotes.text: How are they telling stories? What do these five stories all have in common? They have something in common. There's something that they're all doing, and you can certainly read the tea leaves and try to figure it out.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Offers a repeatable pattern-finding exercise—compare a small sample of stories to infer the publication’s implicit editorial logic.

quotes.topic_title: Prep: pick goals and find your real story
quotes.text: If we're talking about prep, the very first thing that you need to do is what I had said earlier, which is just ask yourself, what do I need press for? And you need a good answer to that question.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Sets a clear first-step framework: define the specific purpose of press before doing any pitching.

quotes.topic_title: Prep: pick goals and find your real story
quotes.text: Because, for example, the story that somebody might tell me at Entrepreneur is going to be different than the story that somebody might tell Cosmo.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Highlights the outlet-specific angle principle—your story should change depending on the publication’s audience.

quotes.topic_title: Prep: pick goals and find your real story
quotes.text: You could think about your story and kind of break it up into a whole bunch of different little pieces and then figure out which piece goes to what media.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Provides a practical methodology: decompose your narrative into modular angles and match each to the right outlet.

quotes.topic_title: Prep: pick goals and find your real story
quotes.text: But oftentimes, people make the mistake of trying to do that in reverse, which is to say that they kind of decide what narrative they would like to have out in the world, and then they just go around to different publications trying to sell them on that.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Counterintuitive warning that the common approach (push one narrative everywhere) is backwards and ineffective.

quotes.topic_title: Prep: pick goals and find your real story
quotes.text: They're really about the audience. They're really me serving the audience through the stories of the people I'm writing about.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Reframes what “a good press story” is: not about the company, but about serving the publication’s readers.

quotes.topic_title: Common press goals beyond awareness
quotes.text: Anything that's tied to growth or reaching a new customer base-
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Reframes press goals from generic awareness to concrete business outcomes like growth and customer acquisition.

quotes.topic_title: Common press goals beyond awareness
quotes.text: But it could also be that you're looking to position yourself in your own marketplace a little differently.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Highlights positioning as a distinct, strategic press objective beyond launches or announcements.

quotes.topic_title: Common press goals beyond awareness
quotes.text: I know why they want to be an entrepreneur. They want to be an entrepreneur because they're trying to position their brand as also being relevant to small business owners.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Provides a concrete example of how large companies use specific outlets to signal relevance to a target segment.

quotes.topic_title: Common press goals beyond awareness
quotes.text: So sometimes it's not even about a conversion, but rather it's about a positioning and that's a good reason to also maybe put forward your executives.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Counterbalances conversion-focused PR thinking by emphasizing executive visibility as a lever for positioning.

quotes.topic_title: Common press goals beyond awareness
quotes.text: Look, there's a million reasons why being visible can be useful, but you need to make sure you understand what you're actually trying to do.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: A practical reminder to define the intended outcome before pursuing coverage, guiding strategy and measurement.

quotes.topic_title: PR agencies: when they help and red flags
quotes.text: PR is and can be, I'll say can be, a very frustrating journey because a lot of PR people are very bad at their jobs. They're very bad.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Sets a realistic baseline that hiring PR is not automatically a shortcut—quality varies dramatically and requires scrutiny.

quotes.topic_title: PR agencies: when they help and red flags
quotes.text: For example, if you hire or talk to a PR agency and one of the things that they recommend doing that you should spend money on is a press release, like a traditional press release, run as fast as you can away from that.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: A clear red-flag heuristic for evaluating PR agencies and avoiding outdated, low-leverage tactics.

quotes.topic_title: PR agencies: when they help and red flags
quotes.text: And zero people are going to see it in the whole world because Yahoo Finance has a section where they just publish every damn press release that gets published by all these different distributors. Nobody saw that.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Explains why wire distribution “placements” are often vanity metrics that don’t translate into real audience attention.

quotes.topic_title: PR agencies: when they help and red flags
quotes.text: What you want in an actual PR person is someone who traffics in one thing, and that is relationships.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Provides a simple selection framework: prioritize relationship-driven PR over output-driven tactics like blasts and releases.

quotes.topic_title: PR agencies: when they help and red flags
quotes.text: You should like when a PR person pushes back on you and says, "You know what? I don't think that your story is right for that publication. Here's why." That's someone you should hire.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: A practical hiring signal: the best PR partners protect relationships and improve fit by giving hard feedback, not just executing requests.

quotes.topic_title: Which publications to target and why
quotes.text: Honestly, it really, so much depends upon what it is that you're looking to do.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Pushes back on generic “top outlets” lists and reframes targeting as goal- and audience-dependent.

quotes.topic_title: Which publications to target and why
quotes.text: They reach people who are in a creating mindset.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for matching publications to the reader’s intent (creating vs buying).

quotes.topic_title: Which publications to target and why
quotes.text: I think oftentimes people tend to think too close to them about where they belong.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Highlights a common founder bias—defaulting to “startup/business” press instead of where customers actually are.

quotes.topic_title: Which publications to target and why
quotes.text: If you have a startup and you're trying to figure out what publications to be in, go look at where your competitors have been featured.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, repeatable starting method for building a relevant media target list.

quotes.topic_title: Which publications to target and why
quotes.text: What audiences are they reaching and how are they doing it?
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Turns competitor coverage into a diagnostic: identify both the audience and the angle/format that earned coverage.

quotes.topic_title: Press as validation: TechCrunch and beyond
quotes.text: But sometimes the point of it is not to reach the people who are reading it at all.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Reframes press as a credibility asset rather than a direct audience-acquisition channel.

quotes.topic_title: Press as validation: TechCrunch and beyond
quotes.text: In fact, the largest possibility here is that your story will reach five to 10,000 people, a small number of people because these publications are publishing tons of stuff.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Sets realistic expectations about reach even in major outlets, helping practitioners measure success differently.

quotes.topic_title: Press as validation: TechCrunch and beyond
quotes.text: Maybe what it really is is to tweet it and then put some money behind promoting that tweet because then you can target that you got coverage to the people who you want to notice you got coverage.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Actionable tactic: turn earned media into targeted paid distribution to reach the right audience.

quotes.topic_title: Press as validation: TechCrunch and beyond
quotes.text: As seen in is probably more valuable than anyone actually reading that story to begin with.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Memorable mental model: the downstream credibility (“as seen in”) can outweigh direct readership impact.

quotes.topic_title: Press as validation: TechCrunch and beyond
quotes.text: And we got coverage in Variety. And that was the result of pounding on a lot of doors and finally getting someone at Variety to take interest and they ran an article about us. Did we get anything from that story in Variety? The answer is no, like nothing. But you better believe that every email we send out to every potential advertiser, to every partner, includes the link. Variety has covered us. And I guarantee that when someone receives that email, it makes them pay more attention.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Concrete example showing how press can fail to drive immediate results yet materially improve outbound conversion via credibility.

quotes.topic_title: Who to pitch: avoid the editor-in-chief trap
quotes.text: So a lot of people make the mistake of emailing me. If they want coverage in Entrepreneur, they email me.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Highlights the common but ineffective instinct to pitch the most visible senior editor instead of the right person for the story.

quotes.topic_title: Who to pitch: avoid the editor-in-chief trap
quotes.text: But I am the busiest editorial guy at Entrepreneur for whatever the hell that's worth. And I'm just not the guy to pitch because my job actually isn't really to select stories that go in the magazine.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Explains why editor-in-chief visibility doesn’t equal story-sourcing responsibility, guiding practitioners to target the true decision-makers.

quotes.topic_title: Who to pitch: avoid the editor-in-chief trap
quotes.text: And so you really should start by looking at who's writing about your subject area.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Provides a simple, actionable rule for identifying the correct pitch target based on existing coverage.

quotes.topic_title: Who to pitch: avoid the editor-in-chief trap
quotes.text: So a good way, again, to do it is to start with the publication and then look at how they're covering your competitors.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Offers a practical research method to find relevant editors/writers and infer the publication’s preferred story formats.

quotes.topic_title: Who to pitch: avoid the editor-in-chief trap
quotes.text: So now next step, who's writing these things? Let's look. Let's open some of the articles. The byline is right there. You can click on the byline. You can see what this person does.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Gives a concrete step-by-step tactic for discovering the right contact and understanding their scope via bylines.

quotes.topic_title: Freelancers are hungry and often more receptive
quotes.text: So Jen, on a day-to-day basis as a freelancer is hungrier for stories than me because Jen has to hustle for her food.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Highlights why freelancers are often more motivated to find and develop story ideas than staff writers.

quotes.topic_title: Freelancers are hungry and often more receptive
quotes.text: Jen has to find stories and pitch those stories to editors at publications, and that's when she gets paid.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Explains the incentive structure that makes freelancers more receptive to relevant pitches.

quotes.topic_title: Freelancers are hungry and often more receptive
quotes.text: And I should add here also, note that a good journalist, a good writer is not actually sitting around thinking that their job is to wait for people to pitch them so that they can just write about the best pitches.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Corrects a common misconception about how journalists work, implying pitches must compete with their own reporting instincts.

quotes.topic_title: Freelancers are hungry and often more receptive
quotes.text: But if somebody reads a story that she wrote and says, "Ah, I think I have an idea of what this person is interested in," and then tracks her email address down and then emails her, Jen is getting a lot fewer pitches than me, the chances of her reading it are close to a hundred percent.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Gives a practical outreach tactic: target freelancers based on demonstrated interests because they receive fewer pitches and are more likely to read yours.

quotes.topic_title: Freelancers are hungry and often more receptive
quotes.text: So sometimes going to the staff person is not actually your best move. Finding the freelancer who's doing the work is sometimes the better move.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: A counterintuitive PR strategy: prioritize the freelancer author over the obvious staff contact to improve odds of attention.
